title: Boris tells Cabinet North Sea oil gas continue Net Zero transition
story: Share this article BP insisted that it is heavily investing the profits it makes back into shifting to lower carbon alternatives to fossil fuels as it announced plans alongside its results to boost investment in renewable energy.For every £1 it earns in the UK, it has committed to spend £2 out to at least 2025, according to the group.Chief executive Bernard Looney told CNBC a windfall tax would not address the current crisis.He said: 'We need more gas, not less gas, and therefore we need to encourage investment into the North Sea and not discourage it.''The second thing is around the transition – we need to accelerate the transition,' he added.BP's results showed a marked recovery from a torrid 2020, when the pandemic sent it slumping 18.1 billion US dollars (£13.4billion) into the red on a statutory basis – its biggest ever annual loss.Oil and gas prices have since rebounded as economies worldwide reopened following the early stages of the Covid crisis, with a demand crunch pushing the cost of crude past 90 US dollars a barrel for the first time in more than seven years.

title: the secret teacher i often correct work that has clearly been dictated
story: With grinds, the very last thing a student who is not working hard enough needs is yet another person working hard on their behalf. Photograph: iStockIn absolute terms our national expenditure on education looks eye-watering. Yet we seem to be making a habit of coming bottom of the OECD rankings for investment in education. Why?Whatever the importance and scale of other items on the expenditure list, the largest single item is salaries of school staff. As a profession, we teachers feel the full weight of every non-teacher’s expertise on all things pedagogical. We live with the total oxymoron of everyone claiming to know all about what we do while simultaneously demonstrating an entire arsenal of evidence that they have never ever stood in front of a class of young people.Many who have done so end up leaving teaching, proving that the fantastic holidays do not balance out the pressures and demands involved in our role. However undeniably wonderful the volume of time away from the classroom might be, those of us who are committed and delivering full value know that we have earned every moment of it.As public servants it is important that we deliver value, and that our fellow taxpayers feel they are getting good bang for their buck. The best way to get that is to look after us, to ensure that we are able to perform optimally. The open abuse the teaching profession is subjected to runs entirely counter to that.For many, when your name is already mud it’s hard to see the incentive in attempting to convert the deep-rooted doubter. It is too often entirely evident that there is no point in trying. I know numerous teachers who actively avoid saying what they do for a living until it is absolutely necessary. Interestingly, they are among the cream of the crop and have earned reputations for their excellence. They give of their best as a matter of conscience.If we have unhappy public servants, and taxpayers who are unhappy with their public servants, isn’t that better addressed than shoved under the carpet? The reality is, we as taxpayers appear slow to ask for more and better of our teachers.A number of alternative avenues seem more appealing.Astronomical feesPaying for the same service a second time elsewhere is most definitely one. Enrolments in fee-paying schools exceeded 26,200 this year, reaching an all-time high. Despite demanding fees of between €5,000 and €10,000 for day pupils, many of these schools have waiting lists. €15,000 is not unusual for five-day boarding, nor €20,000 for seven-day boarding. What makes so many so ready to pay astronomical fees for something they are entitled to courtesy of their taxes?Grinds feature further down the scale but are nonetheless big business. While I’m in no doubt that there are many effective private teachers out there, I’m in even less doubt about how many are doing more damage than good. Parents rush to suggest that they will “get her a grind”, and I usually wince at how obvious it is that they have completely missed my point.The very last thing a student who is not working hard enough needs is yet another person working hard on their behalf. Grinds are far too often well-intentioned but disempowering. Many parents are so relieved to find someone available that they do not find out enough about that person’s suitability. And the youngster getting the one-to-one assistance is not best placed to filter what they are being told.When I see evidence that a student may be being poorly served, I offer to speak to their private teacher. Only once in my career has that offer been accepted and on that occasion the person was entirely suitable. He proved himself an excellent collaborator when we liaised and worked together for our mutual student’s benefit.Regrettably, I often correct work which has clearly been dictated, and which my student has little hope of being able to reproduce and understands only minimally, if at all.When engaging a private teacher and investing additional funds in what is already available via your child’s school, it is essential to establish that person’s suitability for preparing for the specific exam your child will take. We teachers engage in a lot of training for a reason, but there is every chance that the teacher you are paying privately is not accessing that training. In that situation, there is every reason to ensure that you are getting your money’s worth. You could very well be paying someone to unhelpfully contradict what is in fact correct.Keeping schtumWhile we Irish have a reputation for staying quiet and not wanting to make a fuss, there are limits. It is one thing to go out for a meal and decide to keep quiet about being dissatisfied. Chances are, you’ll simply never return to that restaurant. To clearly see flaws in how we provide for educating our youth and yet let those flaws remain makes little sense. Isn’t this precisely the time to seek only the very best? Does it honestly make more sense to keep schtum and throw good money after bad? Or worse still, bad money after bad?It is time we established an inclusive forum for open and courageous exchange around how Ireland could “do” education better. These days mental health, wellbeing and leadership are increasingly linked to growth and learning, which is what our young people are at school for. In the interest of serving them better, that forum would do well to conduct a thorough audit of what we are currently doing and explore ways to improve both what we offer and how we rank in terms of education.

title: first full programme of st patrick s day ministerial visits since before pandemic
story: Ministers will travel all over the world again for St Patrick’s Day. Photograph: iStockMinisters will travel all over the world again for St Patrick’s Day in the first full programme of ministerial visits since before the Covid-19 pandemic.They will visit 33 different places across the world including venues in the US, EU, UK, Far East and Latin America, while in countries where in-person visit are not possible, local embassies will organise St Patrick’s Day events. There are no visits scheduled to Russia or China, which a senior source said was due to “Covid reasons primarily”. Taoiseach Micheál Martin will visit Washington DC for an expected meeting with US president Joe Biden at the White House, and with Congressional leaders on Capitol Hill. He will also visit London the weekend before St Patrick’s Day, though no details of that programme have been released yet. However, he is expected to attend the Ireland-England rugby match at Twickenham.Several ministers will also visit destinations elsewhere in the US. Green leader and Minister for Climate Eamon Ryan will visit New York, while Minister for Public Expenditure Michael McGrath will go to San Francisco, as well as Vancouver on the west coast of Canada.Minister for Education Norma Foley will travel to Boston, while Minister for Children Roderic O’Gorman will also visit New York, and Philadelphia. Helen McEntee, Minister for Justice, will visit Savannah, Georgia in the southern US, while the Minister for Health Stephen Donnelly will travel to Austin, Texas. Chief whip Jack Chambers will go to Los Angeles, while Minister of State Patrick O’Donovan will go to Chicago. Attorney General Paul Gallagher will also travel to Washington.Tánaiste Leo Varadkar will visit Colombia and Chile. Other ministers visiting Latin America include Minister for Arts Catherine Martin (Argentina) and Minister of State Colm Brophy (Mexico).In the EU, Paschal Donohoe, Minister for Finance, will go to the Netherlands (he will also go to London). Minister for Higher Education Simon Harris will go to France Minister of State Pippa Hackett will visit Greece Minister of State Thomas Byrne will go to Italy.Minister of State Ossian Smyth will go to Spain and Portugal, Minister of State Josepha Madigan will go to Slovenia Minister of State Anne Rabbitte will travel to Romania.Minister of State Joe O’Brien will go to Finland Damian English will visit Sweden Mary Butler will go to Belgium Frank Feighan will go to Poland Niall Collins to Croatia and James Browne to the Czech Republic.Elsewhere, Sean Fleming will go to Scotland and the North of England Robert Troy will go to India Peter Burke will travel to Japan and South Korea Martin Heydon will visit Lebanon Hildegarde Naughton will go to Australia and New Zealand.Minister for Housing Darragh O’Brien will visit the Expo in the United Arab Emirates and Minister for Agriculture Charlie McConalogue will travel to Canada. The “minister on call” at home will be Minister for Foreign Affairs Simon Coveney, though he will also attend events “on the island of Ireland”, while Minister for Social Protection Heather Humphreys and Minister of State Malcolm Noonan are both listed as “no travel”. According to the Department of Foreign Affairs, the “central message of this year’s St Patrick’s Day is that Ireland is reopening, and the international programme will focus on the theme of Rebuilding Connections &amp Supporting Communities across the globe.“St Patrick’s Day is the primary flagship for realising the ambition of the Government’s ‘Global Ireland’ programme to promote Ireland as a great place to live, visit, work, study, and invest, with an integrated, all of Government, Team Ireland approach,” the department said in a statement.

title: duchess cambridge opens motherhood visit parental support project
story: The Duchess of Cambridge made fruit kebabs and accepted pretend cups of tea from toddlers, as she spoke of the vital importance of play to building healthy children.The Duchess, who spent time with mothers and toddlers at PACT (Parents and Communities Together) in Southwark today, said she wished she had been able to attend a similar group when she was expecting her first child, admitting she would have “learned a lot”.Helping young children chop and eat fruit to the soundtrack of a catchy song about bananas, she spoke to parents about the importance of a “holistic” system to ensure isolated new mothers and their babies do not “fall through the cracks”.Hearing how PACT runs “Parent University” courses for expectant parents and those with newborn babies, the Duchess heard how mothers were learning about social and emotional development as well as the basics about labour and feeding.“Do you feel there’s enough awareness and understanding around social and emotional development among under 5s?” she asked Josephine Namusisi-Riley, who leads PACT in Southwark.“There’s perhaps more about what they’re eating and what parents are doing about physical milestones?”Josephine and health visitor Simonette Guerra described how the course dealt with the importance of the early years, including brain and language development and play.“As a new mum I would have liked that,” said the Duchess. I think I would have learned a lot.“The importance of play!“What’s so fantastic is seeing the amazing work that’s going on here. That support you’re providing is amazing. The science backs it up.”The Duchess has made a lifelong commitment to working in Early Years Development, reading academic literature that underlines the importance of play as well as closely following new research.Hearing how some new parents worry about their children being “naughty” despite them behaving in a developmentally-appropriate way for toddlers, she agreed: “Behaviour is communication.“Throwing things is all about learning.”She arrived at St Michael’s Church in Camberwell on Tuesday morning, walking around the corner for a low-key greeting while the usual royal police escort parked discreetly out of sight.The mothers taking part in the weekly play session had not been told of their VIP guest until they arrived at the session with their babies that morning.The Duchess was greeted by Josephine Namusisi-Riley, who leads PACT in Southwark, and Mena Amnour, parent organiser of MumSpace, who told her about the group.PACT was set up by Citizens UK in 2014, after local mothers signalled the need for a real-life group to make new friends and receive support.In the pandemic, it provided emergency help to isolated families from giving out laptops to help those who were homeschooling to food parcels, training in how to order prescriptions online, and a regular Zoom meeting for parents to socialise.Josephine told the Duchess they had noticed the particular difficulties of “digital exclusion”, where families with multiple children were trying to work and home school with one laptop between them, did not have Wi Fi connections, and did not speak good enough English to find help.She also told of the numerous barriers local parents faced in reaching support, including stigma, fear of approaching official services or even registering with a GP.“Has the conversation changed since the pandemic?” the Duchess asked, guessing: “It’s exacerbated everything.”“Feeling connected to each other as humans and being able to listen to each other helps with the isolation.“Where families go to find a holistic support system.“So much we say is mental health is having someone to talk to and listen.”She added: “For the child’s journey, being able to link up health with then education, through the community programmes and services like this, is really vital.”Hearing about the baby bank of clothes for struggling families, the Duchess asked: “For the parents and families who come here, are their needs related to food and clothing for the children, as opposed to emotional needs?”She heard how parents usually came with a physical need, before being welcomed with a hug, a cup of tea and a listening ear.The Duchess was invited to join a small group of toddlers and their carers, who were making fruit kebabs for fun and a lesson in healthy eating.The Duchess helped one little boy, Jonathan - who was wearing a smart shirt as he celebrated his second birthday - chop up his banana.His grandmother Grace told her that the sessions were “a lot of children and many, many toys - it’s find to be here”.“Has it helped your relationship with him?” the Duchess asked, breaking off to say “Good job!” to the little boy who was eating nicely.Going to shake the hand of another mother, she laughed “Sorry, now I’ve got a sticky hand” before pulling a face of amazement at one-year-old Zoe who was busy eating strawberries.“I can see why everyone likes it here,” the Duchess said.Later, she joined the main room where new mothers were socialising as they fed their newborns, while volunteers played with older babies and toddlers so their parents had a moment to talk.The Duchess watched children climbing up a frame to go down a slide, and accepted a make-believe ‘cup of tea’, actually full of kinetic sand, from a little boy called George - the same name as her own eldest son.Playing along, she took her mask off for a pretend sip before saying thank you and passing it back to him.The Duchess spent time with Laura Barber, mother of two-year-old Rebecca, who talked about mental health and the challenges of parenting in isolation.“She said if she had had something like this, she would have appreciated it too,” Ms Barber added.Before leaving, the Duchess told staff and volunteers, many of whom arrived at the group as new mothers themselves: “Thank you for your hard work, it’s really impressive. It’s such good fun, I want to go back in there!”Of her work in early childhood development, and making generational change for the children of the future, she added: “It’s going to take a long time, joining the dots. It’s not a quick thing.”Early evidence from a study by King’s College in 2020 suggested that the model used by PACT improves parental mental wellbeing, reduces social isolation, and improves child language outcomes.They found that 40 per cent of the mothers who came to the Mumspace group were at the threshold of getting some form of mental health intervention, with 68 per cent of those assessed as fully recovering within six months.More from NewsPolitics latest news: Row erupts over Cabinet reshuffle as Boris Johnson seeks to reset No 10Farmers told to make countryside more accessible by replacing stiles with gatesThe Tory MPs who have publicly submitted letters of no confidence in Boris JohnsonDonald Trump &#39makes $20m&#39 on coffee table book containing put-downs of his enemiesRussia-Ukraine latest: Emmanuel Macron hails Minsk breakthrough as Moscow and Kyiv agree to talksWes Streeting goes too far... and Sajid Javid cuts him down to sizeMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: must end reliance chinese cctv cameras
story: How would it feel to know that when you are walking down the street you are being watched by the same cameras that support the Chinese surveillance state? For many in Britain, this is not hypothetical. Hundreds of thousands of cameras made by Hikvision and Dahua, whose equipment have been linked to the persecution of Uyghur Muslims, make up the backbone of Britain’s CCTV infrastructure.Last year the US government blacklisted the two companies over national security concerns, but here in Britain the Government failed to heed calls from the House of Commons Foreign Affairs Committee to follow suit. The dominance of Hikvision and Dahua in Britain puts the country’s security, privacy and moral standing in the world at risk.Big Brother Watch has found that thousands of public bodies, and some of the UK’s biggest businesses, use these CCP-linked cameras. Three quarters of local councils are equipped with Hikvision or Dahua cameras, as are more than half of schools and universities and a handful of government departments.Although doing nothing illegal, both companies offer much more than video recording. In Xinjiang, they have developed technology that was once the stuff of a science fiction nightmare and tailored it to the all-encompassing mass surveillance state – from facial recognition on every street corner to cameras sending “Uyghur alerts” to the authorities.Similar tools are on offer in Britain. Some schools have CCTV capable of face or gender detection and the coronavirus pandemic has led to a spike in temperature-scanning camera sales. One school in Yorkshire has much more advanced Hikvision technology, capable of searching CCTV footage by clothing colour, tracking people and even using AI to detect schoolyard scraps or if children are wearing face masks.We are already one of the most heavily monitored populations on the planet. Now, low-cost CCTV cameras are stationed across the country, with Hikvision and Dahua’s pile ‘em high, sell ‘em cheap business models fuelling a boom in high tech surveillance cameras on the side of every other building. For little more than £100, it is possible to buy a camera powered by algorithms that claim to analyse our behaviour, vehicles, and much more.People should be free to go about their daily lives without being watched by such cameras. Britain must push back on the creeping growth of Chinese-style surveillance and do more to protect against backsliding into a world where privacy is a mere afterthought.More from NewsPolitics latest news: Row erupts over Cabinet reshuffle as Boris Johnson seeks to reset No 10Farmers told to make countryside more accessible by replacing stiles with gatesThe Tory MPs who have publicly submitted letters of no confidence in Boris JohnsonDonald Trump &#39makes $20m&#39 on coffee table book containing put-downs of his enemiesRussia-Ukraine latest: Emmanuel Macron hails Minsk breakthrough as Moscow and Kyiv agree to talksWes Streeting goes too far... and Sajid Javid cuts him down to sizeMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: wagatha christie case rebekah vardys aide says leaked coleen
story: Rebekah Vardy’s aide claimed “it was me” who leaked a story about Coleen Rooney to the press, in a series of text messages, the High Court has heard.In the latest round of the “Wagatha Christie” legal battle between the two footballers’ wives, the court was shown text messages between Mrs Vardy and her PR adviser Caroline Watt.According to Mrs Rooney’s written case, messages exchanged between Mrs Vardy and Ms Watt in January 2019 involve the pair discussing a post on Mrs Rooney’s private Instagram account which showed where her car had been damaged.Mrs Vardy told Ms Watt she “would love to leak those stories x”.In January 2019, Mrs Rooney posted on Twitter that one of her Instagram followers, who she had trusted to have access to her private account, was selling stories about her.In a text exchange later that day with Mrs Vardy, Ms Watt said: “It wasn’t someone she trusted, it was me,” followed by a laughing face emoji.David Sherborne, lawyer for Mrs Rooney, told the court on Tuesday: “What we say is that the inference to be drawn from that is that Mrs Vardy knew perfectly well what she was doing, and was behind it and was encouraging it.”The row between the two celebrities started in October 2019, when Mrs Rooney took to social media accusing Mrs Vardy of leaking stories about her private life after carrying out a months-long “sting operation” which became known as “Wagatha Christie”.The wife of former England star Wayne Rooney claimed Mrs Vardy had shared fake stories she had posted on her personal Instagram account with The Sun newspaper.Mrs Vardy, who is married to Leicester City striker Jamie, denies the accusations and is suing Mrs Rooney for libel.Mr Sherborne said Mrs Vardy and her agent Ms Watt were “routinely” looking at Mrs Rooney’s private Instagram stories with a view to having them published.He also said: “Mrs Vardy encouraged her to do this, she knew it was happening. The lack of criticism, let alone surprise, shows it was agreed between Mrs Vardy and Ms Watt.”The barrister told the High Court that Mrs Rooney was making a claim for further information to be disclosed.He added Ms Watt’s phone had fallen into the North Sea after a boat she was on was rocked by a wave.“(It was) most unfortunate, because it was only a short time after the court ordered that the phone should be specifically searched,” he said.More from NewsPolitics latest news: Row erupts over Cabinet reshuffle as Boris Johnson seeks to reset No 10Farmers told to make countryside more accessible by replacing stiles with gatesThe Tory MPs who have publicly submitted letters of no confidence in Boris JohnsonDonald Trump &#39makes $20m&#39 on coffee table book containing put-downs of his enemiesRussia-Ukraine latest: Emmanuel Macron hails Minsk breakthrough as Moscow and Kyiv agree to talksWes Streeting goes too far... and Sajid Javid cuts him down to sizeMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: boris rishi need good neighbours
story: Neighbours, everybody needs good neighbours... but the Boris and Rishi fairytale is going to end in tearsDowning Street has found the perfect blend of bluster and billionaire, says Fleet Street Fox. But how long will Errorsboroughs marriage of convenience last Its the wedding of Rot and Brylcreem - a match made in hellopinionByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsIf thereaposs one thing that Boris Johnson is disciplined about, itaposs control. Specically, not being subject to it. Wedding vows, lockdown rules, basic morality, the Ministerial Code, his own manesto: the default response of the Prime Minister to all of them is PAH! Which is why itaposs interesting that, a week after the worst week in his premiership since the previous worst week, which was only the week before, the PM is now submitting himself to the control of his Chancellor of the Exchequer.In a single weekend, Rishi Sunakaposs mates have moved into No, expensive policy announcements have been binned, and the crime of fraud which has taken £bn off the taxpayer on Covid alone has been downgraded to a harmless infraction of little consequence.  Unfortunately, this whirlwind romance is headed for some very big and pointy rocks.The first is that the cost of living crisis, which is already a crisis, is going to get worse with food costs predicted by millionaires to rise another % in April. No-one knows what to call something worse than a crisis, but the dictionary will probably need updating to include something like crisaster.The second is the energy crisis, in which the taxpayer has been forced to compensate corporate giants for not being able to steal money immediately, and instead letting them steal it over  years. Prices are likely to rise again in the autumn, and because  months was too long for billion-pound firms to wait, the government may allow an extra price rise in the summer to tide them over. Presumably, weaposll be calling this frobbery.If Boris thinks Her Upstairs is dficult to live with, heaposs going to flip when he finds out that Rishi is the sort of spouse whoaposll give him £ towards the housekeeping, and then ask for £ back by exerting some below-inflation fiscal drag on state pensions. On the face of it, their relationship is rooted in shared politics and a mutual love of money. But while one partner is a hedge funder whoaposs got more money than the Queen, the other never carries cash because he canapost hold onto it for more than  minutes.Both of them seem unable to spot a party when it involves  people, soft drinks, beer, renditions of Happy Birthday, a society wallpaperer, an official photographer, a strategically-sly cake, and a police investigation. Both, according to reports, are also capable of enjoying all that in the space of just  minutes before getting on with the job, which is a polite way of saying you burped all afternoon.But thereaposs little  these two have in common. One is a spender, the other a spaffer. One drinks beer, the other power. One is vain enough to arrange photocalls on staircases so he doesnapost look as short, while the other has just one suit and no comb. Read moreToday, weaposre told that a major announcement on Borisapos big promise to use the £bn National Insurance increase to bring down NHS waiting lists has been boiled down to a website, so that you can stop ringing the doctor to find out about your appointment and just throw the computer out of the window instead.Officially, the plan isnapost ready yet, and unofficially Rishiaposs blocking it until heaposs PM and can announce it himself. And therein lies the problem with this partnership: only last week, Johnsonaposs friends were telling him to kick Sunak out, on the grounds he was trying to steal his job.Imagine a bride trying to get the groom sacked, withholding cash while giving it to rich mates, giving Princess Diana eyes in TV interviews whenever sheaposs asked about parties. Picture a groom so desperate to keep the house that heaposll overlook their dferences, let her take total control, and start measuring up for curtains he will never get to see.Think about a relationship in that much trouble before its second anniversary. It might work in an Australian daytime soap, but it ainapost going to last in a world where people donapost come back from the dead after  years lost at sea. Johnson thinks heaposs saved his skin by ceding control to his most ambitious enemy, and boasts it would now take a Panzer ision to get him out of No. Sunak, meanwhile, is quietly lining up his tanks in the Downing Street garden, which he has always had a great view of from his No office. The PM is being infantilised by enemies saying his we wields all the power, and potentially criminalised by his friends claiming that she has nothing to do with his work, but nevertheless attended a lot of work events.And the only PR expert who can be persuaded to enter the fray is someone who considers the PM sexually incontinent, throws Benny Hill salutes at world leaders, quotes Gloria Gaynor, and on his first day gives the press the headline: Heaposs not a COMPLETE clown. But the fundamental flaw with this great reset, which is probably more of a breather to allow Rishi to liquidate assets, is that it involves trying to instil discipline in a man who has spent a letime shucking it. The fact he needs to be taught the self-control of a toddler is why he lives in Errorsborough - a town twinned with Débâcle.Fans may think these two have found the perfect blend of bluster and billionaire, but itaposll last only as long as it takes for Johnson to take back being out-of-control, and Sunak deciding that his tanks are ready to evict. title: expat tells tories pay up
story: Expat tells Tories to pay up after pension frozen at £ a week for  yearsBrian Green, , from Billinge, Merseyside, emigrated to Australia in  meaning his UK state pension was frozen at £ a week and hes never benefited from the yearly increases others getBrian Green, , is furious as his state pension is ‘frozen’ at £ per week Image: End Frozen Pensions YouTubeByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Feb |comments An expat retiree has told the Government to pay up after his state pension was frozen at £-a-week for  years.Brian Green is among an estimated half a million Brits living abroad whose pension payments no longer increase at the normal rate.The -year-old, originally from Billinge near Wigan, Lancashire, moved to Queensland, Australia, with his we in  to be closer to the coupleaposs daughters, reports the . The majority of British nationals see their pension go up yearly as high as . percent, in line with average earnings or inflation under the triple lock. Even though this policy has been temporarily suspended, most will be expecting a rise this year. The Government says increases are only guaranteed for those living in the UK, the European Economic Area , Gibraltar, Switzerland and countries with a social security agreement with the UK . Mr Green and his we - who did not wish to be named - were born and lived in the UK all their lives before emigrating. Speaking to the End Frozen Pensions campaign, the pensioner said: Our pensions have been frozen for some  years. I receive £., and my we receives £..Are you affected by a pension freeze  Let us know at webnews@mirror This, I believe, is immoral. If we had chosen to live in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo or Turkey, or indeed  other countries with which the UK has a bilateral or reciprocal arrangement, our pensions would not have been frozen. Mr Green appeared to accept the idea the UK Government will not pay backdated pensions to impacted expats across the globe. However, he added: But they could start paying the full and entitled pensions from now. Today. Since leaving their home shores, Mr Green and his we have ed annually for two months. But Mr Green highlighted their pensions undergo a temporary change when they reach Britain. He continued: “During that stay, we received an increased entitlement to our pensions.  “So on Monday, when I set off, my pension is frozen in Australia. On Tuesday, when I arrive, my pension is thawed. “What does it matter where I am ” Mr Green is keen to highlight the issue which is thought to affect hundreds of thousands of people across the world. He concluded by urging the government to take action, and said: “I paraphrase the words from Sir Henry Newbolt’s splendid poem: Vitai Lampada. “Government - pay up! Pay up! And play the game.” A DWP spokesperson previously said: “We understand that people move abroad for many reasons and that this can impact on their finances. “There is information on GOV.UK about what the effect of going abroad will be on entitlement to the UK state pension. “The Government’s policy on the up-rating of the UK state pension for recipients living overseas is a longstanding one of more than  years and we continue to uprate state pensions overseas where there is a legal requirement to do so.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Department for Work and PensionsFrozenState pension" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: new housing minister landlord who
story: New Housing Minister is landlord who defeated law to make homes fit for human habitationBoris Johnson made Stuart Andrew Englands th housing minister in  years after Chris Pincher left following two years service - and it quickly emerged he voted down a hotly-contested amendment in Stuart Andrew has been moved from Deputy Chief Whip to Housing Minister, the th in  years Image: Getty ImagesByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsBoris Johnson has appointed Englandaposs th housing minister in just  years - and he is a landlord who voted down a bid to make all rented homes fit for human habitation.Deputy Chief Whip Stuart Andrew was today moved to Housing Minister in Boris Johnsonaposs mini-reshuffle as part of a clearout of the whipsapos office. The current Housing Minister, Chris Pincher, was shunted aside. Until now heaposd been the longest-serving Housing Minister for more than a decade, with two yearsapos service. Housing campaigners have previously reacted with dismay at the constant churn of dferent ministers while England faces a housing crisis.Mr Andrew faces a bitter battle with the Tory grassroots as he and Housing Secretary Michael Gove rework controversial plans to tear up the planning system. Mr Gove shelved the plans to split areas into development loans and theyaposre being examined again.He will be in charge of meeting the target to build , homes a year. A post on Mr Andrewaposs website declares Save Our Greenbelt, opposing a plan for , houses in the next  years in and around Leeds. Feb  - Present Stuart Andrew Feb  - Feb  Chris Pincher July  - Feb  Esther McVey July  - July  Kit Malthouse Jan  - July  Dominic Raab Jun  - Jan  Alok Sharma July  - June  Gavin Barwell July  - July  Brandon Lewis Oct  - July  Kris Hopkins Sept  - Oct  Mark Prisk May  - Sept  Grant Shapps Meanwhile, it quickly resurfaced that Mr Andrew voted against a legal bid to make all rented homes fit for human habitation. The amendment to the Housing and Planning Bill was voted down - on  January  in a major row. Tory ministers said the amendment would cause unnecessary regulation and cost to landlords, and councils already have strong and effective powers to police poor-quality homes. Minister Marcus Jones said at the time that it would deter further investment and push up rents for tenants. Of course we believe that all homes should be of a decent standard, and that all tenants should have a safe place in which to live regardless of tenure. But local authorities already have strong and effective powers to deal with poor quality and unsafe accommodation, and we expect them to use them. But Labouraposs Teresa Pearce said at the time: Although it is true that the majority of properties are safe and fit to live in, it is unacceptable that, in , we still have people up and down the country living in properties unfit for human habitation. This clause would change the lives of many tenants and provide a more robust, secure and safe private rented sector, which surely we all desire.  It later emerged  of the Tory MPs who voted down the amendment were also landlords. Pudsey MP Mr Andrew owns a house in nearby Leeds which brings in more than £, a year in rental income.It comes after Jacob Rees Mogg was sacked as Commons leader and made Brexit minister as Boris Johnson launched a mini-reshuffle to distract from weeks of Tory chaos and scandal.The Prime Minister is reshaping his top team after being deserted by a series of No aides and the Met Police launching an investigation into  rule-busting parties in Downing Street during lockdown. Arch-Eurosceptic Mr Rees-Moggaposs full title will be Minister for Brexit Opportunities and Government Efficiencies and he will be a member of Cabinet. Meanwhile, Chief Whip Mark Spencer replaces Mr Rees Mogg as Commons leader and Tory MP Chris Heaton-Harris will head the whips office. Mr Spencer has kept his seat at the Cabinet table, however, despite weeks of criticism over the top Toryaposs handling of the Owen Paterson lobbying row. title: 6 strict new dvsa driving
story: All  strict new DVSA driving test changes that could be enforced in MONTHSUK drivers have been forced to adjust to a whole host of Highway Code changes recently, and now learners will need to be wary of six new DVSA driving test changes that could be coming in months. Heres everything you need to knowThe DVSA has proposed six changes to driving tests Image: Getty Images iStockphotoBySurena ChandeSEO Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsPreparing for driving tests can be daunting, with Highway Code revision to cram into your brain and hopes of a smooth run when out for the test itself. After a range of new Highway Code changes were enforced on January , , it seems budding drivers will have to brush up on their knowledge of the rules. And, with the pandemic causing chaos for driving test and theory test bookings, it seems there could be more trouble ahead for those looking to pass their test and get behind the wheel. The Driver and Vehicle Standards Agency DVSAhas proposed a range of changes to driving tests due to demand being at the highest it has aposever knownapos. Due to the scarcity of test slots, it has caused many learner drivers to book in tests far earlier than they are ready for.So, here are all of the DVSAaposs proposed changes for driving tests that could be enforced in just months. What are the DVSAaposs six proposals for driving test changes in   . Ensuring learner drivers are prepared for their driving test  Perhaps the most crucial element for budding drivers is that being prepared for your upcoming driving test is more vital than ever. The proposal suggests extending the amount of time you will need to wait before rebooking a car driving test, after failing one, to  days — you currently need to wait just  days.This move is also being pushed to allow for more training time to prevent retakes from being done with no further training. The DVSA states that, due to long waiting lists for lessons, slotting in time for extra training is tricky for driving instructors.With the proposed -day extension, there is a greater window of opportunity for learner drivers to take top-up lessons so they are better prepared for the car driving test.  This change would apply solely to car driving tests. The following would not be affected by this:other types of driving tests, such as motorcycle tests, heavy goods vehicleand bus driving tests theory tests approved driving instructortests. Forcing learners to give more notice for car driving test cancellations Finding time for a driving test booking can be tricky due to shortages of slots, and all sorts of surprises can crop up in day-to-day le leading to test cancellations. Therefore, it comes as no surprise that , driving tests were cancelled between April , , and December , , alone. The new proposal suggests forcing learner drivers to give  days of notice when cancelling their car driving test to avoid losing their fee. They currently only need to give three days of notice when cancelling a car driving test.  This would not be enforced for reasons like bereavement, illness and other circumstances decided by the DVSA. The change would allow for fewer driving test slots being wasted, and therefore it could potentially lead to a higher volume of tests being available to book. When the fee loss policy was temporarily lted during the pandemic, the DVSA found that there was an increase in tests being cancelled at the last minute. This reduced signicantly upon the fee loss police being reintroduced for short notice period cancellations. . Identying data surrounding how well driving instructors prepare learner drivers  The DVSA has proposed a method to easily identy which driving instructors need the most help and support with providing high-quality training. It suggests introducing a legal requirement for them to display their approved driving instructoror trainee driving instructor registration certicate in the windscreen of their car when brining people to driving tests. The DVSA explained the reasoning behind this, and said it would:encourage driving instructors to only bring people for their driving testthey’re confident they will pass help us improve our ability to identy and prioritise which driving instructors most need help and support to provide high-quality training mean that we can treat all driving instructors bringing pupils for tests consistentlyCurrently, driving instructors are only legally required to do this when carrying out driving lessons, but not for driving tests. However, many do so voluntarily.  If enforced, DVSA driving examiners would record the instructoraposs personal reference number and the test results can then be linked back to them. This would then allow the DVSA to identythe driving instructor needed a standards check. The proposal could mean that driving instructors who refuse to display the certicate could lose the approval to teach. It would also help the DVSA to identy and remove instructors from the register who are not offering high-quality training. . Offer more information about driving instructors to learners  While learner drivers can currently see the name, phone number, email address and distance of the driving instructor, the DVSA is pushing for more transparency. The proposed changes are displaying the following information deduced from a rolling -month period:average number of driving faults their pupils make per test average number of serious faults their pupils make per test percentage of the driving instructors’ pupils tests where the driving examiner had to take physical action in the interests of public safety overall pass rate for the driving instructors’ pupils. Changes to learner driver eyesight checks during driving tests  The DVSA has suggested a change in the law surrounding driver eyesight checks during driving tests, with the ability to do eyesight checks in dferent levels of light and use ious methods to test eyesight. At present, the law only allows for eyesight checks in good daylight and the test involves reading a registration plate on a parked vehicle up to  metres away. The changes would apply to car, motorcycle, tractor, specialist vehicle and approved driving instructorand part driving tests.  The move would allow for more flexibility for driving test times offered, and to ensure drivers meet eyesight standards under a range of conditions. Additionally, it would prevent test cancellations when there is poor light. . Swapping paper pass certicates for digital pass certicates The DVSA has proposed paper pass certicates for driving and theory tests should be swapped for digital versions. If passed, this will apply to all driving tests and would be in-line with the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agencyefforts to create a digital driving licence.  The move would not only prevent people from losing physical copies, but it is also likely to help the environment with a lack of need for over two million sheets of paper printed annually. Why are the driving test changes being proposed by the DVSA and when would they be enforced  The DVSA has proposed these six driving test changes due to a a range of factors, but it is predominantly due to a vast increase in demand for driving tests. The website states additional reasoning for the change proposals, with the hopes that they will:encourage learner drivers to be better prepared for their driving test help to reduce the number of driving test appointments that are wasted give us more flexibility in how and when we can carry out driving testsWhen will the DVSA driving test changes be decided and how can I have my say The DVSA encourages people across the UK to have their say about the driving test changes on its website.The consultation vegan on January , , and will close at .pm on March , . Following the responses, the next steps will be decided and published within three months of the consultation closing, so by June , . title: boy 3 who helped workmen
story: Boy, , who helped workmen near his home has his day made after they bring special gtJack McDonough was rewarded with his own hard hat, high vis jacket and his first ever pay packet after helping out the workers with his lively chat and tea carrying skillsJack McDonough with his new friends Image: Liverpool EchoByKelly-Ann MillsNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsA three-year-old boy has received his first wages after he helped gas engineers near his home as he went to and from nursery. Jack McDonough watched keenly when workers from Cadent Gas and BCH Civils were working outside his house in the Childwall area of Liverpool. Having brought out cups of tea and chatting to engineers Simon, Dave, Ian, Andy and James while he was on his way to and from nursery, the three-year old was rewarded with his own hard hat, high vis jacket and his first ever pay packet.Jackaposs mum Steph told Liverpool Echo : He just loves anything and everything to do with construction so, on the way to and from nursery every day, he went to say hello to them and they would say hello back.He was just in heaven and the fact that they were so kind to him - we stood on our wall and just watched them dig for about an hour - they were just talking to him every day. They would involve him and talk to him - they were just really kind, asking him about his day at nursery. We gave him some cups of tea and biscuits to take out when they were working outside ours because they were so kind to him.Jackaposs involvement and interest in their work paid idends. Steph added: One day as we were walking down to nursery, one of the engineers said that he would come and knock on later because they had a gt for him. It was a little hard hat, a gt bag, a little high vis jacket and a wage packet with £ in for him to say thank you for being so helpful. It was just lovely - it absolutely made his day. They had been so kind to him the whole time but that was above and beyond. Compensated for his labour and with his interest in construction bolstered further, Jack still keeps an eye out for his colleagues, who Steph said left a lasting impact on him. She added: Now whenever he sees anyone in an outfit that’s sort of similar, he’ll say ‘there’s my friends’. Though he has not yet started primary school, Steph says Jackaposs heart is set on a career in engineering. She added: Whenever we take him out and there are roadworks, he makes us drive the way of the roadworks so that he can watch them. He absolutely loves it. Our house is full of construction-related toys. He’s got a ride-on excavator that he goes out and ‘digs’ with, so to have them outside our house was amazing.Jenny Moten, North West Network Director, Cadent, said: “This all went a bit under the radar - the team didn’t go looking for any praise, they just wanted to make Jack’s day. So it was lovely to hear Jack’s parents speak so highly of them. Let’s hope we can maintain Jack’s interest and have him a fully-fledged member of the team in years to come.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON HousingPeople" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: couple face choice between heating
story: Couple face choice between heating and eating within weeks of newborn daughter arrivingLeonnie Shinells and Jamie Scott from Hull knew they faced tough challenges ahead when their baby arrived but they have already chosen eating over heating as the cost of living crisis hitsMadisons parents chose eating over heating Image: Leonnie ShinellsByKelly-Ann MillsNews ReporterJoseph Gerrard:,  Feb |commentsA young couple who recently welcomed their first child has spoken out about the dficulties choosing between eating and heating. Leonnie Shinells and Jamie Scott from Hull knew they faced tough challenges ahead.But within weeks of daughter Madison arriving, the cost of living crisis had already hit home. Jamieaposs working hours in retail were suddenly cut so much the pair turned off their heating so they had enough money to eat and feed their baby.Jamie, , said: I know there’s talk at the moment between people having to choose between heating and eating and we’ve literally been in that situation recently. Itaposs not a choice any new parents wants to have to make. Are you struggling with the cost of living crisis  Email webnews@mirror to tell your storyI work in retail and my hours were cut, so we decided to go without heating. Leonnie, , and Jamie say there is little comfort in the Governmentaposs promises of a -year plan to level up the North and give -week-old Madison the same opportunities as a child born in the relative comfort of the south.Their story was highlighted by Hull Live in the newspaperaposs shocking coverage on the cost of living crisis.A photo of little Maddison featured on the front page with the headline: Donapost Leave Us Behind. Babies born in Hull in  are likely to be less healthy, less wealthy and less qualied as they grow up compared to those in Michael Goveaposs Surrey constituency. Will his aposlevelling upapos plan really give these children a fair chance , the paper asks. Jamie told the paper: “I don’t feel like there’s been enough support from the council or the NHS. “There’s no heating in Leonnie’s mum’s flat at the moment, it’s freezing.  “It happened a couple of weeks ago, I work in retail and my hours were cut, so we decided to go without heating. “We feel like we’re in the early stages of Madison’s le at the moment so we haven’t thought about education too much. “But we both want to make sure she does as well as she can when she starts school because we’ve both said that not trying when we were there was one of our biggest regrets. “We didn’t realise what the consequences would be at the time. “We’ll be encouraging her to try and get a good job as well, we weren’t able to do as well as we liked because we didn’t work hard enough at school.”Leonnie said: “Health-wise it’s been hard for us, I’ve had support from my family but after  weeks I’m still waiting to hear back from the NHS. “I didn’t really feel listened to during my pregnancy either.“I’ve felt a bit on my own and living’s dficult when weaposre at my mums because she’s only got a one bedroom flat. The Bransholme area in Hull is on paper an area which will benefit from the Government promises delivered by Mr Gove last week to level up some of the Northaposs most deprived towns and cities within the next decade. The Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities said the plans heralded the beginning of the end of decades of deprived areas being forgotten and left behind. The plans, spearheaded by Secretary of State Gove, promises more powers for local areas, better public transport, greater investment and an end to illiteracy and innumeracy.  Levelling up promises to improve parts of the North such as Bransholme, one of the most deprived parts of Hull according to the Index of Multiple Deprivation . The IMD, which scores areas based on education, health, housing, crime, employment, their living environment and access to services, ranks Hull itself as among the most deprived cities in England. In contrast, Office for National Statisticsfigures which compare dferent places on a range of measures exposes the gulf between Hull and Mr Goveaposs southern constituency Surrey Heath. The IMD shows that Madison and other Hull newborns will grow up in a city with the th highest levels of income deprivation affecting children. A baby born in Surrey Heath meanwhile would live in an area which ranks th on the same measure. The Government has promised to close the gap by , but Jamie and Leonnie do not have the luxury of years when it comes to raising Madison. They said they already felt they had been left to bring up their baby daughter on their own, with worries about work, housing and education a part of daily le.For both Prime Minister Boris Johnson and Levelling Up Secretary Mr Gove, their plans for people like Jamie and Leonnie should give them hope.The prime minister said: It is the most comprehensive, ambitious plan of its kind that this country has ever seen and it will ensure that the government continues to rise to the challenge and deliver for the people of the UK. Mr Gove said: Levelling Up and this White Paper is about ending this historic injustice and calling time on the postcode lottery. story: Disastrous Plenty of Fish first date ends up in court after mans dog bites womanAlan Dean, , met Carol Durie on the Plenty of Fish dating app and had hoped his Welsh Collie Freddie would delight his date - however the dog became aggressiveAlan Dean, , with his beloved Welsh Collie Freddie Image: WALES NEWS SERVICEByAdam AspinallNews Reporter:,  Feb |comments A dog owner had a nightmare first date - after his jealous pet Collie bit his new woman and he was hauled to court. Alan Dean, , was hoping his pet Welsh Collie dog would delight Carol Durie after meeting on the Plenty of Fish dating app.The pair arranged to meet up for a first date - and were joined by Dean’s beloved Welsh Collie called Freddie. A court heard they went for a countryside walkies in the village of Llanymynech, Powys, when they decided to go back to Dean’s home. Victim Miss Durie was alone in the room with the dog - when Freddie “pinned” his paws on her shoulders.  Magistrates heard Dean had been out of the room making a drink when his pooch sunk his teeth into Ms Durie’s hand and forearm. Miss Durie told the court the dog had been acting aggressively throughout the afternoon in September . She said the dog “should have been muzzled” - and that the previous owner had told Dean that he “should have been put down”. The court heard Dean claimed that his pet had only reacted when Ms Durie’s tried to push him away.  He said Freddie had not had any trouble before or after the incident. Magistrates said: “Ms Durie was a credible and consistent witness and has a long history of animal experience. “Alan Dean was consistent in his belief of the truth of his evidence but his demeanour changed under cross-examination from the prosecution.” Dean, of Oswestry, was found to be in charge of a dog out of control and given a community order with a pm to am curfew. He was also ordered to pay £ in compensation by Telford magistrates. A contingent destruction order was also issued for Freddie, who must be muzzled in public and only walked by someone over the age of . story: Dozens of over s given out-of-date Covid jabs at UK vaccination centreNHS Grampian has confirmed that  out-of-date Covid vaccinations were administered in Stonehavens town hall on  February - those affected are being contactedFollowing an investigation, NHS Grampian have confirmed that this is an isolated incidentImage: Dinendra Haria SOPA Images REX ShutterstockByKeiran FlemingDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  Feb |commentsAn NHS health board has been forced to apologise after dozens of over-s were given out of date Covid vaccines. NHS Grampian has confirmed that  out-of-date Covid vaccinations were administered in Stonehavenaposs town hall on  February.Those who were affected by the botch are now being contacted directly by the health service. It is believed the doses are safe and will still protect but health bosses say there is a very small possibility of reduced effectiveness.Following an investigation, NHS Grampian have confirmed that this is an isolated incident and all those affected were over , Aberdeen Live reports.A spokesperson said: “We can confirm  people who attended Stonehaven Vaccination Centre on  February were given a COVID- vaccine which was later discovered to be out of date. We are offering re-vaccinationthose affected want this. We are contacting them directly to apologise and to offer them this, according to their personal circumstances. We would like to take this opportunity to apologise publicly for any distress or inconvenience. This comes as Professor Sir Chris Whitty has written to unvaccinated NHS staff telling them it is their professional responsibility to get vaccinated. The chief medical officer for England tweeted out the letter on Tuesday, saying: I have written to NHS colleagues about the professional responsibility to protect patients from Covid-. This includes getting vaccinated, as the great majority have. It has also been signed by chief midwery officer Professor Jacqueline Dunkley-Bent, chief nursing officer Ruth May, and NHS medical director Professor Stephen Powis, among others.Health Secretary Sajid Javid told the Commons last month that ministers plan to scrap a legal requirement for frontline NHS staff in England to be vaccinated against Covid. He said ending the policy, which also affects social care staff, is now under consultation in light of the Omicron iant, which is less severe than the Delta iant.In the letter, Sir Chris and others say that professional responsibility and legal mandate are separate things, adding: Our professional responsibility is to get the Covid- vaccines as recommended, to protect our patients. At the same time, the vaccine protects us. The great majority of healthcare workers have already done so. We hope that those of you who have not will consider doing so now. title: family boy 11 who survived
story: Exclusive: Family of boy, , who survived car collision say blood donors saved his leCharlie Golden, , was knocked down by a car while crossing the road outside his home. The young boy suffered fractures and was saved thanks to two blood transfusionsCharlie Golden pictured in hospital after the car collisionByMartin BagotHealth and Science editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments The family of an -year-old lad who miraculously survived a horror car collision have told how heroic blood donors saved his le.Charlie Golden was crossing the road outside his home when he was knocked down by the car. The ferocious impact tore off the youngster’s scalp and left him with his pelvis fractured in four places. Medics had to hold his head for five hours because they couldn’t stop the bleeding. Two blood transfusions eventually saw him pull through. His mum, Lauren, explained the then eight-year-old Charlie was leaving their house in Aylesham, near Canterbury, Kent, on his way to show friends a shortcut to a local park. “His dad Paul called out to Charlie to be careful on the road, like he always did, and watched them cross from the window,” she told the Mirror.  “That’s when he saw the car hit our boy, right outside the front door. “He just shouted, ‘He’s been hit’, and ran out of the door. “Paul and a neighbour basically held his head together and started to stem the bleeding.” Charlie’s injuries were so severe he was put into a coma on the roadside before being airlted to King’s College Hospital, in London. He remained in a critical condition for  hours while two blood motorbikes sped extra blood to the hospital to keep him alive. “He would have diedthere had not been enough blood available,” said Lauren, who has since become a champion of giving blood, encouraging friends and family to become lesavers as well. “I remember lying next to Charlie in his hospital bed and really wishing that I had donated,” she said. “A few days after the accident, I put an appeal on Facebook to family and friends pleading with them to donate as I knew the generosity of others saved my little boy’s le. “Blood is one of those things you just expect to be there when you need it, but I hadn’t stopped to consider where it comes from.” As it stands the NHS is , regular blood donors short of what it needs to recover from Covid-.With stocks in England now supplied by the smallest ever pool of donors this century, the Mirror is campaigning for readers to help make up the critical shortfall.Around three quarters of a million people kept hospitals in stock at the height of the pandemic, but this was , fewer than the year before.A third of blood given goes to patients undergoing emergency surgery. A stranger’s generosity meant Charlie survived. His brain injury means he has some learning dficulties. And Lauren and husband Paul now regularly give their own blood. Lauren said: “The other day, I received a text telling me which hospital my blood has been issued to. “All I could think of were those amazing people who received that same text when their donation saved my Charlie’s le. “Without someone, somewhere, donating, he would have died.” How you can help Register as a blood donor today and play your part in the NHS recovery. Patients need blood all year around and the NHS needs to ensure a steady supply. In some areas of the country there are limited appointments for first time donors soyou cannot find a slot straight away please search a few weeks or months ahead. story: Family loved the hotel they holidayed at for  years so much they bought itAndrew Long and his family stayed at the hotel, known as the Polurrian on the Lizard, through several summers over the past  yearsThe -bedroom propertys communal areas were refurbished in  Image: POLURRIAN HOTEL APEXByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsA holidaymaker loved the hotel he and his family stayed in over the last  years so much that he bought it.Andrew Long, from Lincolnshire, took his family to the Polurrian Hotel in Cornwall for their summer holidays countless times over the past three decades. But Mr Long and his family loved the hotel so much, he is now its sole owner after concluding the purchase of the Hotel Polurrian Limited.He has also bought the surrounding  acres of grounds, part of the Polurrian Cove beach. He said: We are delighted to have acquired the Polurrian, which has many happy memories for my family, since first discovering this wonderful location some  years ago.  We are proud to own this iconic hotel and to further endorse our Cornwall connections, with regular visits for business and pleasure each year. This is a going concern transaction and all employees at the Polurrian, including the General Manager, Grant Callaghan, will continue to be employed. The new owners have also entered into a management agreement with the vendor group, Luxury Hotel Management Limited.  The agreement will remain under the control of Nigel Chapman, an established and experienced hotelier. Mr Long, the buyer, is a co-founder of the Extra Motorway Services Areas Group, where he continues to be CEO and an ongoing investor. He has some  years of property and operational experience in the hospitality and roadside sectors and has a number of plans for further investment in the Polurrian to enhance the existing facilities. Mr Chapman, Principal of Luxury Hotel Management said: We are delighted to be working jointly with Andrew and his team.  Itaposs great to see the next chapter for the Polurrian successfully unfolding and to know that there will be a signicant further investment into this much-loved hotel. Polurrian on the Lizard first opened in . It sits in an elevated location with views across Mounts Bay and Mullion Island. The new owners said they will retain links with aposFriends of Polurrian Coveapos and other local groups in Mullion and the surrounding Lizard area. The -bedroom propertyaposs communal areas were refurbished in . The Polurrian includes the Vista Lounge with its ocean views, a decadent bar area, restaurant with Gozney woodfired oven, games room, spa, gym and pool. title: football fan peter crouch bum
story: Football fan with Peter Crouch bum tattoo is barred from games for  yearsThe -year-old Stoke City fan has been handed a five-year ban due to his unacceptable behaviour at football gamesJack is banned from attending all games in the U.K or abroadByMichele Theil:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsA football fan who tattooed aposI love Peter Crouchapos on his bum has been given a five-year match ban for unruly behaviour.Jack Heath, , has been banned because of persistent unacceptable behaviour at both home and away fixtures in recent years, the Stoke Sentinel reported.The order will also prevent him from associating with fellow fans on match days in the geographical exclusion zones. He was found to have caused or contributed to violence or disorder while at Stoke City games, and now cannot attend any football match here in the U.K or abroad. He will have to surrender his passport when England play away games and is prevented from watching England play at Wembley stadium. Jack is a huge Stoke City fan, having even tattooed aposI love Peter Crouchapos on his bum, referring to the professional footballer who played for the team between  and . He revealed that he got the tattoo while on holiday in Magaluf last year, captioning an image shared to social media with: It must be true loveI think about you when Iaposm drunk, tagging Crouch at the end. The full tattoo reads: Oopsy Daisy, Stoke are crazy, I love Peter Crouch. The former striker replied to Jackaposs post by saying: Iaposm proud of you Jack. Iaposm sure you will never regret this. The case was brought to the North Staffordshire Justice Centre by Staffordshire Policeaposs Football Policing Unit, whose evidence prompted the sentence. PC Ben Greensides, from the Football Policing Unit, said: We welcome the outcome and hope this sends a strong message that this sort of behaviour at football matches will not be tolerated. Incidents of poor behaviour will be investigated and those seeking to ruin match days for genuine supporters will face such consequences.A recent report by the BBC showed that arrests of football hooligans has risen in recent years, with the police attempt to further crack down on bad behaviour.Baroness Casey, who led a report into mass disorder at the Euro  final, called out the culture around disorder at football matches a big challenge and asked for a change in attitudes towards support behaviours. title: grieving mum who held dying
story: Grieving mum who held dying son in arms thought his body was rubbish bag in streetPaula Allen, aged in her s, fought back tears as her -year-old sons killer was sentenced to six years and eight months in prison at Manchester Crown CourtPaula Allen pictured with her son Marcus Image: Marcus Simmons-Allen  Cavendish PressLtdByALEC WHITAKERLaura SharmanNews Reporter:,  Feb |comments A mother told how she spotted what she thought was a bag of rubbish dumped in the street - only to find it was her teenage son dying in the road following a hit and run crash. Council worker Paula Allen had gone out looking for Marcus Simmons-Allen, , after being alerted about the impact near their family home. But she ended up being first on the accident scene and cradled the youngster in her arms as he lay fatally injured. Moments earlier Marcus, who was due to start his first day of college, had been run down at mph and left to die by Connor Matthews, , who was driving a stolen car. Despite the teenaposs mum and dadaposs efforts to revive him, Marcus succumbed to his injuries in hospital the following morning.At Manchester Crown Court, Mrs Allen who is in her s fought back tears as Matthews, from Stretford, was jailed for six years and eight months. The court heard how the motorist had no driving licence and had previously been issued with as ASBO. Mrs Allen said in a statement: aposFinding my son that night, like a bag of rubbish fly tipped at the side of the road, haunts me. aposaposI was the first person at Marcusaposs side, holding him, trying to find his pulse. His leless body, my son dying in my arms. Time stood still. My precious son was going, fading. I found myself running into the road, stopping the traffic and screaming, pleading for anyone to help, for anyone to save him. aposaposI knew he was in a bad way, really bad. As mothers we are there to love, mend, fix, provide and advise. I was now helpless trying to save my sons le.  Emergency services and strangers were fighting to keep Marcus alive. As the short hours passed, we had to accept that Marcus could not and would not ever survive. The tragedy occurred on October  last year after Marcus had popped out to buy a pint of milk with his friend Connor Kelly. Both checked for oncoming cars as they were about to cross a dual carriageway but as they set off, Matthews who was on his way to a party suddenly appeared in a VW Scirocco driving at high speed. Marcus attempted to jog across the road in an attempt to get to the other side but had barely got two paces when he was hit by the vehicle. Prosecutor David Lees said: aposaposHe was hit by the car and flung through the air landing some distance away. Matthews then slowed before driving off again.  Connor Kelly called out to a pedestrian to call the police then decided to run back to Marcusapos house to tell Ms Allen. He then ran back to the scene and stayed with his friend until the paramedics arrived. aposMs Allen recalled how she had just got into her car when she saw Connor in a state of panic, the court heard. He shouted aposcome quick, come quick it was Marcusapos and she drive off looking for her son, it was said. Mr Lees continued: aposaposShe could not see anything initially so turned the car around. It was then that she could see something that she initially thought was a bag of fly tipped rubbish on the road. To her horror she then realised that it was her son.aposapos  In her statement read to the court Mrs Allen told how she pulled up just before where Marcus was laying and put on her hazard lights. I think I shouted at Connor who had gone to the floor in horror upon arriving on foot to where Marcus lay, she said. aposaposHe was lying face down on the pavement approximately . metres from the lamp posts down from the crossing area where Marcus got hit by the car. I screamed at Connor to ring an ambulance and the police. The mum checked Marcusaposs body to seehe was responsive and noticed a gaping wound on his right eyebrow and his right eye was swollen, she said. She discovered a pulse and reassured her son including in the ambulance.  Marcus was described by his family as aposaposvery loving and joyousaposapos person who had been working towards his degree in engineering. aposUnfortunately the day he sadly passed away was supposed to be his first day at college, his mum added. His death has ripped our family apart. My son left the house to walk with his friend and never ed home. aposaposThe point of physical impact that caused Marcusaposs death is visible from my driveway, just a short  meters from our property. aposaposWe as a family are unable to leave our home to complete everyday tasks such as, buying bread and milk, leaving to attend work, doing the school run and other general errands without the reminder and the flashbacks of that horric night in which our lives changed forever.  aposaposSince the incident, Mrs Allen said the family have had to find another way around the estate because they cannot bear to drive past the site where flowers still lay at the roadside. The VW was found dumped a mile away and inquiries revealed it has been stolen from a house in Oldham the previous month. Matthews was arrested at a house in Liverpool five days later. He admitted knocking down Marcus before aposapospanickingaposapos and driving off. The court heard Matthews had  previous offences on his record including robbery, criminal damage and possessing cannabis and had been issued with an ASBO which he repeatedly ignored. He was banned from driving in  for driving without insurance or a license. In mitigation his lawyer Dominic Thomas said: aposaposThe defendant is profoundly sorry and he always will be for what he has done. It has been a deeply harrowing experience for Marcusapos family and there is no possibility of putting any of that right. He knows it will always be profoundly unfair he is here when Marcus is not.aposapos  Sentencing Matthews, Judge Hilary Manley told him: aposaposMarcus was just starting to find his feet in adult le and you took that le and all the promise and hope of his future from him. You have never held a driving licence, but that clearly hasn’t held you back from driving when you feel like it and it didn’t stop you from making the clear decision to get behind the wheel of a powerful, stolen vehicle and to casually treat it as your own, driving to a party, and thereafter, giving a lt to a friend. aposaposYou were travelling very rapidly and struck Marcus with force. I you had not been driving when you were not permitted to drive, and at such a grossly excessive speed, he would be alive today. aposaposMarcus’s mother had to find him where he had been flung, on the road, alone, looking like a discarded bag of garbage that had been fly-tipped. aposaposBy making yourself scarce, you have ensured that the police have not been able to establish whether or not you had been drinking or taking drugs at the party you attended before getting behind the wheel.aposapos aposaposMarcusapos brutal and untimely death has robbed him of his future. You have a young child but he will never know what it is to be a parent. You can look to a future that will start up again upon your release, when you are still only in your mid-twenties. He has no future and his family have nothing to look forward to which will not bring with it the searing ache of his absence.aposapos Matthews was also banned from driving for five years which will start when he is freed.
